They lost hundreds of millions of dollars to delayed planes. 

According to Porter, “late flights and cancellations generated a thousand complaints a day.” 

The CEO was eventually fired. 

The moral of the story: ignoring trade-offs is a terrible strategy. 

This strategy is terrible for organizations and for people. 

Have you ever spent time with someone who tries to fit in more? 

Such people know they have ten minutes to walk to a meeting. 

They still sit down to answer a couple of emails first. 

Or they agree to put together a report by Friday. 

They have another huge deadline that same day. 

Or they promise to attend their cousin’s birthday party on Saturday night. 

They already have tickets to a show that starts at the same time. 

Their logic, which ignores trade-offs, is “I can do both.” 

The important problem is that this logic is false. 

Inevitably, they are late to the meeting. 

They miss one or both deadlines or do a shoddy job. 

They either don’t make it to their cousin’s celebration or miss the show. 

The reality is that saying yes to one opportunity means saying no to others. 

Trade-offs are real in both personal and professional lives. 

Until we accept this reality, we’ll be like Continental. 

We’ll be stuck in a “straddled strategy.” 

This forces us to make sacrifices we might not choose. 

In an insightful op-ed for the New York Times, Erin Callan shared her sacrifices. 

She was the former CFO of Lehman Brothers. 

She wrote, “I didn’t start out with the goal of devoting all of myself to my job.” 

It crept in over time. 

Each year, slight modifications became the new normal. 

First, she spent a half-hour on Sunday organizing her email. 

Then she worked a few hours on Sunday, then all day. 

Her boundaries slipped away until work was all that was left. 

Her story demonstrates a critical truth. 

We can make hard choices for ourselves. 

Or we can allow others to decide for us. 

In my work, I’ve noticed senior executives struggle with trade-offs. 

They are among the worst at accepting this reality. 

I recently spent time with the CEO of a company.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Ignoring the reality of trade-offs leads to poor outcomes in both personal and professional contexts.
